body: @runseb Did you have a chance to take a look at this one?
Changed to strings. Will merge.

Thanks.

We should just wait with merging this until we decide when to include it in a release since it's a breaking change if people used integers directly.

I'm fine with including it in 0.20.0 (next "major" release), but we also need to update documentation (upgrade notes) to reflect this change.

Might want to add some tests for this one. Trying to instantiate a driver in the different regions.
Also I am struggling to understand how the endpoint in the different regions gets selected. Your mapping only shows the paths.
Do not merge. This authentication works for Google Service Accounts and Installed Apps, but threw out the S3 XML API authentication. I need to revise this to make it work with both.

I've updated this PR as follows:
- each region is a separate entry: `google_asia`, `google_europe`, `google_us`
- I added sorting to all keys, taking into account numeric substrings and treating them as numbers, so that an entry such as `"12GB"` sorts after `"3GB"` rather than before (lexicographically)
- reformatted the entire file so that it's now in the canonical format (which also converted numbers like `0.090` -> `0.09` possibly due to `simplejson` library)
- added a utility library to do the above and tests for it
I don't use it but seems quite nice, so if it can help you I am merging it.

Ok so the paths proxies to the correct endpoint.
When you add a few tests I will merge it.

@erjohnso @Kami so we will need a blank commit with "This closes #573" to get it closed.
Or @abpoms you can close it manually.

@djoume can you close this PR manually since @erjohnso closed it.
Or @Kami @erjohnso shall we close it with a blank commit "this closes #529"
@runseb I just pushed with tests to verify the endpoints. My code seems to work :)
looks good, merging
I'm working on this. Please wait for a few days.

Thanks.

I will test it and have a look at some the time permits. It's also worth noting that a while back, I also pushed some Python 3 related fixes - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/d38712ee0f0be8f84d2fde835f23ed08e5f5dc17

Thanks.

The change looks good to me, but I will wait on @runseb or someone else with more CloudStack experience :)

Thanks.

LGTM

Thanks.

I confirmed UnicodeDecodeError doesn't occur when Python 3 is used.

I'm curious, which version of Python are you using?

I created a server with unicode characters in the name and LIBCLOUD_DEBUG worked fine with Python 2.7.8.

It would also help if you can include actual response you get with curl so I can try to reproduce it that way :)

Made a small change to use kwargs to make it more explicit (59ce9031b854bc29926596f627bd0a6e271a1dd5) and merged patch into trunk. Thanks!

On a related note - looks like a similar bug exists here - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/71d4e5718ce5abd8f725084e3858a7075617a008/libcloud/compute/drivers/cloudstack.py#L1384, but I wasn't able to confirm it since we don't have any test fixtures which exercise that code path (ips is always an empty list) and I don't have easy access to CloudStack installation right now.

Can you please have a look?
Would appreciate if you can sync this branch with latest trunk so I can apply patch directly (I've merged 767 first and now there are conflicts).

Thanks.

Besides the params thing, looks good to me so far.

As far as the networking goes, we should also look into reviving this - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/345
@parthiv777 I'm a bit confused, what's this PR supposed to do? :)

Sorry for the delay.

Added some comments.

@ZuluPro Thanks. Next time please mention my nickname, since if you are not replying to my comment, I don't get a notification.

As far as tox changes go, I get this error:

``` bash
kami ~/w/lc/libcloud (git:trunk)$ tox
ERROR: unknown environment 'py3.5'
```

Is this functionality only available in newer versions of tox or is there something else going on?
Actually, ignore my last comment. I just noticed python3.5 is not defined in `basepython =`map. I will fix this.

There is also an issue with pypy

``` bash
ERROR:   pypypy: could not install deps [-r/home/kami/w/lc/libcloud/requirements-tests.txt, lockfile, paramiko]; v = InvocationError('/home/kami/w/lc/libcloud/.tox/pypypy/bin/pip install --pre -r/home/kami/w/lc/libcloud/requirements-tests.txt lockfile paramiko (see /home/kami/w/lc/libcloud/.tox/pypypy/log/pypypy-1.log)', 1)
```

Looks like the issue is related to paramiko (pycrypto) dependency unable to install locally (probably missing some dependency). Will have a look.

Updated .travis.yml to also run tests with Python 3.5 and merged those changes into trunk, thanks!

P.S. I still have problems running tests under pypy locally (looks like an issue related to pycrypto on Fedora under pypy), but I went ahead and merged it since it passes on Travis.

Thanks for those changes again - I didn't know tox supports this notation, it looks much better and there is less duplication now.
@Kami: Any news ?

I didn't know you updated the PR - next time please mention my nick in the comment since I only get notifications if you directly reply to my comment :)

I will have a look asap, but it might take a while since I also plan to sign-up for Aurora objects and test it out.

@Kami @erjohnso 

This is the proposed driver type, please provide initial feedback whilst I prototype implementations for 3 providers.

Proposed drivers are:
- Azure VM Backup
- Amazon EBS Snapshots
- Dimension Data Cloud Backup
- Rackspace Cloud File Backup

Azure VM Backup concept and architecture - https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/backup-azure-vms-automation/
Amazon EBS snaps -  http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-creating-snapshot.html
Also compliant to OpenStack "Freezer" proposed API https://github.com/openstack/freezer-api

Setup branched docs for review here:
http://libcloud-fork.readthedocs.org/en/libcloud-769_backup_driver/index.html
lgtm - thanks @mbrukman!
Thanks for this @mbrukman! Sorry for the long wait.

I don't know other providers very well, but it sure looks like a good fit for Azure and Freezer and likely a few others.

I'm not sure I see such a fit though for AWS and Google since they don't have a "backup-as-a-service" API.  How do you see this working for those two?

Amazons solution has always been either using EBS snaps or Glacier and some scripts. This model would fit EBS snaps well, where the Target is the Volume. I stashed a quick prototype using the existing ec2 compute driver functions for snaps and it works well. 
Google I need to do research on.
Thanks @mbrukman, sorry about the goof.
@erjohnso committed an EBS driver for doing snaps (a bare bones version of one)

For google compute, there would be 2, for GCE- https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/persistent-disks#snapshots and for Google SQL there is a backup and restore function matching the same pattern.

Reviewed Rackspace API, matches to pattern suitable for a driver (need to investigate whether this service is still active) https://developer.rackspace.com/docs/cloud-backup/v1/developer-guide/#document-developer-guide
all good to merge+close?

Alright, I merged the changes. Thanks.

Here is what I did:

``` bash
git fetch dd
git checkout LIBCLOUD-770_Wait_for_state
git rebase trunk  -> that's the important part since it replayed your changes on top of trunk so the changes were now in the mergable order
git format-patch trunk --stdout > 1.patch
git checkout trunk
git am --signoff 1.patch
```

I also made a small change - I supplied default value for poll_interval and timeout argument and changed exception message to also include response body - 4a742436775f83d73c6f0b2a762c6fe2f777c6f1. Let me know if the response.body change looks OK.

would response.body have any value?

here's an example of me using it>

so ex_get_vlan returns a DimensionDataVlan object instance, which doensn't
have a body attribute.

driver.ex_wait_for_state('NORMAL', driver.ex_get_vlan, result['id'])

Alright, I've pushed a fix in - 232f9491f6ad62f8c6db8239f1291575c60b0f81.

Another minor feature improvement would be to change the method signature to `(state, poll_interval, timeout, func, *args, **kargs)`. This way you can partially apply the function, e.g.:

``` python
wait_for_vlan = functools.partial(self.wait_for_state, state=foo, func=self.ex_get_vlan)
vlan = wait_for_vlan(...)
```

Or you could even modify the method to return an already partially applied function which user can use directly.

my python knowledge doesn't extend that far. I was only just up to
functools.wrap
maybe soon I'll know what you're talking about!

Also, you'll see the notes in there about maintaining branches in your own fork for each ticket, which is also good practice and comes in handy if a PR isn't closed and you want to open another one.

I think this is fine, although I don't really understand the testcase. That often means it is too complex (too much mocking). I'm used to pretty heavy mocking but it took me three times to get it. Maybe some docs on how you mock the inner request but test the outer request?
Also, sorry about the delay
And finally, a big thank you for the effort. It can be disheartening when your work doesn't make it into a release, so. Thanks.
@atsaki this was closed by mistake as we are trying to close some old PRs. Can you reopen again, I will merge this week.
@Kami, ping. Sorry if that's annoying, this is blocking a Google-internal dependency of mine.
@runseb I reopened https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/641.
Can you squash your commits ?
I squashed my commits.

As far as test fixtures go - I would recommend to use actual responses you get back when talking to the API.

Maybe times before we encountered an issue with out of date or incorrect docs (I just encountered that issue with CloudFlare DNS driver a couple of days ago - some of the responses in the docs were incorrect and out of date). Sadly it looks like most of the provider documentation is still written manually and not automatically generated from code.
Changes look good to me, but I will wait for @erjohnso to do a final review and merge it.

@crunk1 - can you squash your commits and rebase to trunk? I'm having a heck of a time applying the patch.  That should also trigger a new travis run too, so we can get the assurance that the last failure was a flake.
